item.title: The Sun Is Also a Star Review: Yara Shahidi & Charles Melton Elevate Teen Romance
item.description: The Sun Is Also a Star is a diverse romance that bucks Hollywood's YA genre.

item.title: Saint Bernard Review: Incredibly Bizarre Yet Oddly Compelling
item.description: An increasingly insane musician befriends a dead dog's head in this insane mind-bender from Gabe Bartalos starring Warwick Davis.

item.title: John Wick 3 Review #2: A Tsunami of Gunplay & Mind-Blowing Action
item.description: Action junkies prepare for a blissful overdose, Keanu Reeves is on the run in John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum.

item.title: All Creatures Here Below Review: Karen Gillan Shines in Dark Indie Drama
item.description: A poverty stricken couple flees their criminal acts. The second feature from veteran actor David Dastmalchian and director Collin Schiffli.

item.title: John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum Review: Keanu Kills It Yet Again
item.description: Keanu Reeves still kills it just as much as ever, if not more, in John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum.

item.title: The Hustle Review: Consistent Humor Masks an Inconsistent Plot
item.description: Anne Hathaway and Rebel Wilson in The Hustle are bounds away from being a great comedy, but it's still a fun one.

item.title: Detective Pikachu Review #2: A Slow Start with A Killer Finish
item.description: Detective Pikachu starts out as a mediocre movie but ends up ultimately saving the best for last.

item.title: Tolkien Review: Legendary Lord of the Rings Author Gets Dreadfully Boring Biopic
item.description: Lord of the Rings writer J.R.R. Tolkien's youth is explored in a melodramatic biography that's not really worth the effort, starring Nicholas Hoult.

item.title: Detective Pikachu Review: Pokeman Fans Rejoice, Everyone Else Not So Much
item.description: Detective Pikachu will be adored by the fan base but mystify everyone else, as Ryan Reynolds takes on the voice of everyone's favorite Pokemon.

item.title: UglyDolls Review: A Lifeless Attempt at Fabricating A Trolls Rip-Off
item.description: Uglydolls lacks originality and is filled with bland, one-note characters.

item.title: The Intruder Review: A Painfully Foolish Thriller
item.description: Dennis Quaid is wasted in the brainless and predictable horror dud, The Intruder.

item.title: Avengers: Endgame Review #3: The Biggest Movie Since Lord of The Rings
item.description: Avengers: Endgame hits all the marks in one of the most unprecedented finales in film history.

item.title: Avengers: Endgame Review #2: A Perfectly Balanced Finale
item.description: Avengers: Endgame arrives to answer most of the questions fans have had over the past year.

item.title: Avengers: Endgame Review: A Staggering, Sweeping Epic (Spoiler-Free!)
item.description: The densely plotted, three hour runtime has emotional highs that will hit fandom like a freight train.

item.title: Long Shot Review: Seth Rogen & Charlize Theron Strike Comedic Gold
item.description: Long Shot will warm your heart and tickle your funny bone. It is the comedy to beat at the summer box office.

item.title: Breakthrough Review: A Misled Plot Overshadows A Stunning Performance
item.description: The saving grace of Breakthrough comes in the form of its star Chrissy Metz, who gives an absolutely stunning performance.

item.title: The Curse of La Llorona Review #2: A Bland Horror Flick with No Character
item.description: The latest addition to The Conjuring Universe is nothing special.

item.title: Red Joan Review: Judi Dench Is Wasted in Dull Spy Drama
item.description: Red Joan turns an incredible true espionage story into a boring film.

item.title: Disneynature: Penguins Review: A Heartwarming, Hilarious & Stunning Adventure
item.description: Disneynature hits a home run with their thirteenth feature, Penguins is an amazing look at the beloved birds.

item.title: Stockholm Review: Ethan Hawke & Noomi Rapace's Bizzare Hostage Drama
item.description: Stockholm is the film adaptation of the 1973 bank robbery that coined the Stockholm Syndrome.

item.title: Hellboy Review: A Pile of Garbage, But Still Fun
item.description: Hellboy turned out to be another remake no one wanted, needed or deserved, but there is still a little fun to be had.

item.title: Little Review: Marsai Martin Shines in Silly Update of Big
item.description: Little is goofy and predictable, but delivers big laughs from a good cast that is headlined by breakout star Marsai Martin, Regina Hall and Issa Rae.

item.title: Missing Link Review: Amazing Visuals Elevate Dry Plot
item.description: Missing Link entertains, but isn't in the realm of Laika Studios classic films.

item.title: Mary Magdalene Review: Rooney Mara & Joaquin Phoenix's Dull Apostle Tale
item.description: Mary Magdalene is told with great reverence, but fails to be compelling even with such prolific actors as Rooney Mara and Joaquin Phoenix.

item.title: The Best of Enemies Review: An Inspiring Story Told the Wrong Way
item.description: Taraji P. Henson and Sam Rockwell star in the dramatic true story The Best of Enemies.

item.title: Pet Sematary Review #2: A Solid Remake of Stephen King's Horror Classic
item.description: Audiences will get a shiver down their spines from the wickedly atmospheric chills in this remake of Stephen King's Pet Sematary.

item.title: Shazam! Review #2: An Immensely Entertaining Origin Story
item.description: Shazam! arrives in theaters to shake off the dreariness that has plagued the DCEU since Man of Steel.

item.title: Justice League Vs. the Fatal Five Review: Classic Heroes, Mediocre Story
item.description: The Bruce Timm inspired DC superheroes fights the 30th century's worst bad guys in Justice League Vs. The Fatal Five.

item.title: Camp Death III in 2D! Review: A Horror Movie Loving Heart Worn on A Blood-soaked Sleeve
item.description: I wanted a funny horror movie that was going to blow the lid off the genre. Camp Death III in 2D! delivered.

item.title: Tone-Deaf SXSW Review: Too Much Comedy Sours Robert Patrick Home Invasion Flick
item.description: While Tone-Deaf offers plenty of great moments, the movie ultimately suffers from an abundance of absurdity.

item.title: The Highwaymen Review #2: A Boring Hunt for Bonnie & Clyde
item.description: Despite star turns from Woody Harrelson and Kevin Costner, The Highwaymen is dreadfully slow for the majority of its runtime.

item.title: The Mustang Review: A Powerful Story of Redemption
item.description: A hardened convict must tame a wild horse in a dangerous Nevada prison in The Mustang, starring Matthias Schoenaerts and directed by Laure de Clermont-Tonnerre.

item.title: Dumbo Review: Tim Burton's Baby Elephant Soars
item.description: Tim Burton's live-action adaptation of Dumbo captures the emotions of the classic cartoon.

item.title: Peanut Butter Falcon SXSW Review: Shia LeBeouf Is at His Best in This Fun Adventure
item.description: Shia LeBeouf's character assists a man with Down syndrome with his pro wrestling aspirations in The Peanut Butter Falcon.

item.title: Us Review #2: Beware of Who Lurks in the Darkness [Spoiler Free]
item.description: Get Out director Jordan Peele successfully avoids the sophomore slump with the enthralling horror masterpiece Us.

item.title: Shazam! Review: A Fun DC Movie That Changes the Superhero Game
item.description: Shazam has the future of the DCEU looking a whole lot brighter.

item.title: Stuffed SXSW Review: Taxidermy Doc Is More Beautiful Than You'd Think
item.description: The new documentary Stuffed takes the ick factor out of taxidermy by exploring the unusual art form.

item.title: Dragged Across Concrete Review: A Shockingly Violent, Slow Burn Crime Thriller
item.description: Mel Gibson and Vince Vaughn star in an unflinchingly brutal tale of police corruption with Dragged Across Concrete, from director S. Craig Zahler.

item.title: Extra Ordinary SXSW Review: A Charming Little Paranormal Comedy
item.description: Will Forte and Maeve Higgins star in the horror/comedy Extra Ordinary, a loving send-up of the paranormal horror genre.

item.title: Us Review: A Terrifying Beginning Turns Absurd [Spoiler Free]
item.description: Us has a scary as hell, brilliant first act but the rest of the film doesn't hold up to scrutiny.

item.title: Pet Sematary Remake SXSW Review: Sometimes New Is Better
item.description: Directors Kevin Kolsch and Dennis Widmyer hauntingly reinterpret Stephen King's Pet Sematary for the big screen.

item.title: Curse of La Llorona SXSW Review: The Next Chapter in The Conjuring Universe
item.description: First time director Michael Chaves tackles a real-life horror tale from Mexican folklore in the latest chapter of the Conjuring universe.

item.title: Art of Self-Defense SXSW Review: Eisenberg Shines in Pitch Black, Poignant Comedy
item.description: Director Riley Stearns takes a dark look at masculinity through the lens of karate in The Art of Self-Defense.

item.title: Yardie Review: Idris Elba Directs an Uneven Jamaican Gangster Flick
item.description: Idris Elba's directorial debut has a great soundtrack, but Yardie struggles as a crime drama.

item.title: Never Grow Old Review: John Cusack Terrifies in Dark Western Thriller
item.description: An outlaw gang overtakes a frontier town in the bleak Never Grow Old starring John Cusack, Emile Hirsch, Deborah Francois and Danny Webb

item.title: Body at Brighton Rock SXSW Review: Never, Ever Go in the Woods Alone
item.description: Roxanne Benjamin crafts a terrifying, isolated horror flick with Body At Brighton Rock, her solo feature directorial debut.

item.title: Little Monsters SXSW Review: Lupita Nyong'o Kills It in Australian Zombie Comedy
item.description: The Australian zombie movie Little Monsters is one of the very best titles to be shown at this year's SXSW.

item.title: Good Boys SXSW Review: These Boys Are The Best Bad Boys Ever
item.description: Jacob Tremblay becomes our unexpected new favorite R-rated comedy star in Good Boys.

item.title: The Highwaymen SXSW Review: Bonnie & Clyde Go Down in Style
item.description: Kevin Costner and Woody Harrelson deliver an excellent one-two punch in The Highwaymen as the men who took down Bonnie and Clyde.

item.title: The Beach Bum SXSW Review: The Role McConaughey Was Born to Play
item.description: Harmony Korine returns with his follow-up to Spring Breaks with The Beach Bum, a hilarious and dark stoner comedy for the modern age.
